descriptions: Student does not ask questions about the situation or problem.
Student asks a question that is not relevant to the situation or problem.
Student asks a simple question that is somewhat related to the situation or problem.
Student asks relevant questions to gather basic information about the situation or problem.
Student asks probing questions to gather detailed information about the situation or problem, showing some understanding of its complexities.
Student asks insightful and comprehensive questions that demonstrate a deep understanding of the situation or problem and its underlying causes.
Student makes no observations about the situation or problem.
Student makes superficial observations that are not relevant to the situation or problem.
Student makes basic observations that are somewhat related to the situation or problem.
Student makes relevant observations and provides some details about the situation or problem.
Student makes detailed observations, noting specific aspects and providing clear descriptions of the situation or problem.
Student makes insightful observations, identifying patterns, connections, and underlying causes within the situation or problem.
Student does not gather any information about the situation or problem.
Student gathers irrelevant or inaccurate information.
Student gathers a small amount of information, but it lacks depth or relevance.
Student gathers sufficient information from provided sources to address the basic problem.
Student gathers information from a variety of sources and begins to synthesize it to understand the problem more fully.
Student independently gathers comprehensive information from diverse sources, critically evaluates it, and synthesizes it to develop a deep understanding of the problem.
Student does not attempt to define the problem.
Student provides a vague or inaccurate definition of the problem.
Student identifies a general problem but lacks specific details.
Student defines a simple problem related to the situation that can be solved through a new or improved object or tool.
Student defines the problem clearly, including specific details and constraints, and links it to the desired change or improvement.
Student defines the problem comprehensively, including all relevant details, constraints, and stakeholders, and articulates its significance and potential impact.
